introduction.p: Sage comes equipped out of the box with not just one but several sophisticated permutation suites. While this is good news, it means that some implementations are suitable for certain tasks and other implementations are suitable for other tasks.

subsection.title: The Permutation class
subsection.p: The first class of permutations we will observe is Permutation. Let's look at the help file!

We see that this class takes a variety of inputs, but the fact of the matter is that a Permutation object wants to be treated combinatorially, so the methods are less group-theoretically oriented. The default notation in this class is one-line notation.

convention.statement:
It is critical to notice that Sage, and SageMathCloud, treat multiplication of permutations as right multiplication. There are very good reasons for this, but it is not the convention we have established. Practically this means that if we define
g \amp = \verb|洧링洧맀 洧 洧맅 洧맇 洧 洧맆 洧맂 洧맃 洧맄 洧링|, \amp h \amp = \verb|洧 洧링 洧맅 洧 洧맄 洧맆 洧맇 洧맃 洧링洧맀 洧맂|,
then by our mathematical convention gh = \verb|3 10 8 4 7 6 2 5 1 9|. Let's see what Sage says:
g = Permutation([10,9,5,7,8,6,2,3,4,1]) h = Permutation([8,1,5,9,4,6,7,3,10,2])
# Creating our product "manually" print [g(h(i)) for i in [1..10]]
# Now let's see what Sage does print g*h
This occurs precisely due to Sage's use of right multiplication:
g = Permutation([10,9,5,7,8,6,2,3,4,1]) h = Permutation([8,1,5,9,4,6,7,3,10,2])
# Creating our product "manually" gh_list = [g(h(i)) for i in [1..10]]
list(h*g) == gh_list
You have two choices: you can either remember and adopt the right-multiplication convention, or you can sidestep it by using the Permutation.left_action_product(...) method.
Permutation.left_action_product?

subsection.p: A serious deficit of the Permutation class is that it does not permit direct calculation of powers of permutations.

subsection.title: The PermutationGroup class
subsection.p: We can side-step this problem using the PermutationGroupElement constructor instead of Permutation, which computes the permutation as an element of an appropriately-sized symmetric group.

sage.input:
g = PermutationGroupElement([10,9,5,7,8,6,2,3,4,1]) h = PermutationGroupElement([8,1,5,9,4,6,7,3,10,2])
print g print g^2
print (h*g).tuple() print tuple(g(h(i)) for i in [1..10])

subsection.p: We see from this example that objects of type PermutationGroupElement prefer the disjoint cycle notation, and this is explicit in the name: the objects are algebraically determined as members of a group. We also see that they allow powers of permutations to be directly calculated, and that PermutationGroupElement also assumes right-multiplication.
Further, in order to see the one-line notation of a PermutationGroupElement, one either can use the tuple method of that class or convert to an object of type Permutation.

subsection.title: Which is better?
subsection.p: Simply put: neither or both. They're both fully developed classes, and you can use them for many of the same functions. Since we are interested in using permutations for the purpose of encryption, and it's often important to see the cycle structure. We'll adopt from this point on the cycle notation.
